entry.title: Every time I read articles about SF Symbols, I‚Äôm amazed by the animations, the customization, and...

author.name: Readaggregator - iOS, Swift, Apple, Programming, Mobile

entry.content:
Please open Telegram to view this post
VIEW IN TELEGRAM
Every time I read articles about SF Symbols, I‚Äôm amazed by the animations, the customization, and how polished everything looks. I think: maybe next year I‚Äôll finally sneak them into a real app‚Ä¶

Spoiler: yeah‚Ä¶ probably never. Most of these ideas live happily in pet projects and playgrounds.

Maybe there are some lucky people in this chat actually using them in production? If so ‚Äî envy! As the year ends, here‚Äôs my little wish for all of us: may next year finally give us a project brave enough to let us play with them for real! üòé

https://nilcoalescing.com/blog/AnimatingSFSymbolsInSwiftUI/

#SwiftUI #animations

Animating SF Symbols in SwiftUI - Nil Coalescing
Add symbol effect animations and transitions to symbol images in SwiftUI to handle icon state changes without custom drawing or animation logic.

Recently had to animate a SwiftUI sheet resizing itself ‚Äî sounds like a super basic thing, but the actual solution was anything but obvious.

If you ever need an animatable, auto-sized sheet, this write-up breaks down an approach. Might save you a couple of hours (and some sanity).

https://clive819.github.io/posts/animatable-auto-sized-to-fit-swiftui-sheet/
#SwiftUI #Layout

Animatable Auto-Sized-To-Fit SwiftUI Sheet - Clive Liu
SwiftUI‚Äôs sheet modifier is a fantastic tool, but it comes with limitations: it doesn‚Äôt automatically resize to fit its content. Apple introduced the .presentationSizing(.fitted) modifier in iOS 18 to address this issue. However, let‚Äôs be realistic‚Äîconvincing‚Ä¶

entry.title:
Apple quietly dropped a few nice App Store updates.
The biggest one ‚Äî you can finally submit a...

author.name: Readaggregator - iOS, Swift, Apple, Programming, Mobile

entry.content:
Apple quietly dropped a few nice App Store updates.

The biggest one ‚Äî you can finally submit a new version, while another build is still under review. üôå

Other small but welcome changes:
‚Ä¢ Up to 70 custom product pages per app (each with unique keywords).
‚Ä¢ Offer codes now work for all IAP types, replacing old promo codes by March 2026.

https://www.macrumors.com/2025/10/29/apple-developer-app-store-updates/
#AppStore

Apple Announces Three App Store Updates for Developers - MacRumors
Apple today added new features and expanded flexibility to its App Store review process. Developers are now able to submit additional items for review when an existing submission is already under review. Apple has provided several examples of what can be‚Ä¶

TIL If you are experiencing poor performance with SwiftUI‚Äôs List + ForEach, you can enable the launch argument:

-LogForEachSlowPath YES


https://x.com/kyleswifter/status/1979849200222531959
#SwiftUI #layout #optimization

Kyle Ye (@KyleSwifter) on X - X (formerly Twitter)
For anyone struggling with SwiftUI's List + ForEach's bad performance, you can enable "-LogForEachSlowPath YES" in your launch argument to make SUI log warning for you.

entry.title: Xcode 26 is out, so if you‚Äôre wondering whether to opt into Main Actor isolation in Swift 6.2,...

author.name: Readaggregator - iOS, Swift, Apple, Programming, Mobile

entry.content:
Xcode 26 is out, so if you‚Äôre wondering whether to opt into Main Actor isolation in Swift 6.2, Donny Wals wrote a short piece that helps you weigh the pros and cons before flipping the switch.

For UI packages, main actor isolation makes sense since almost everything should run on the main thread.

For SPM packages like Networking, it‚Äôs less obvious ‚Äî you might prefer to make types Sendable or design them as actors instead of forcing everything onto the main thread.

When in doubt, isolating to the main actor is usually a safe default ‚Äî and you can always mark code that needs concurrency with @concurrent later.


donnywals.com/should-you-opt-in-to-swift-6-2s-main-actor-isolation
#concurrency #swift

Should you opt-in to Swift 6.2‚Äôs Main Actor isolation? ‚Äì Donny Wals - Donny Wals
Swift 6.2 comes with some interesting Concurrency improvements. One of the most notable changes is that there‚Äôs now a compiler flag that will, by default, isolate all your (implicitly nonisolated)‚Ä¶

If you‚Äôre still on Claude Code ‚Äî this might be the perfect time to give it a try. At least until Claude ships an updated model and we all switch back again. üòÖ

#LLM

entry.title: Apple docs are already frustrating and often not very helpful for developers, and on top of that,...

author.name: Readaggregator - iOS, Swift, Apple, Programming, Mobile

entry.content:
Please open Telegram to view this post
VIEW IN TELEGRAM
Apple docs are already frustrating and often not very helpful for developers, and on top of that, LLMs can barely make sense of them: try loading a page with an LLM and all it sees is a JavaScript error: ‚ÄúThis page requires JavaScript. Please turn it on and refresh to view content.‚Äù The extra scripts and clutter make it nearly unreadable. üò¶

Thankfully, Mattt from NSHipster created this service ‚Äî it strips out the junk and turns docs into clean, AI-friendly Markdown. Just swap the domain and your LLM finally gets it.

Can‚Äôt help it‚Ä¶ AI posts keep coming. üí•

https://sosumi.ai
#LLM

sosumi.ai - Apple Docs for LLMs - sosumi.ai
sosumi.ai provides Apple Developer documentation in an AI-readable format by converting JavaScript-rendered pages into Markdown.

entry.title: Former Apple engineers built an AI-powered IDE that runs entirely on your iPhone. You can chat with...

author.name: Readaggregator - iOS, Swift, Apple, Programming, Mobile

entry.content:
Former Apple engineers built an AI-powered IDE that runs entirely on your iPhone. You can chat with an agent to create Swift apps, and thanks to an embedded Swift interpreter, it compiles everything on-device.

The wild part? You can instantly push your build to TestFlight from the app. Super cool‚Ä¶ but also, why?

Demo: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=CUlWhF3ERME

https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=45041185
#AI

Launch HN Bitrig Demo - YouTube
Vibe code, test, and deploy Swift apps. All from your iPhone.

entry.title: Turns out it‚Äôs not just you struggling with trailing whitespace when using Claude Code ‚Äî it‚Äôs...

author.name: Readaggregator - iOS, Swift, Apple, Programming, Mobile

entry.content:
Turns out it‚Äôs not just you struggling with trailing whitespace when using Claude Code ‚Äî it‚Äôs an actual bug. Many thought it was about misconfigured CLAUDE.md or ignored instructions, but nope, the model just loves leaving those extra spaces. ü´†

There‚Äôs a neat way to handle this using built-in hooks. Configure a PostToolUse hook to run SwiftLint, and it will automatically clean up trailing whitespace after each action. No manual cleanup needed.

https://samwize.com/2025/08/25/how-to-fix-claude-code-trailing-whitespace-problem-for-swift/
#LLM

How to Fix Claude Code‚Äôs Trailing Whitespace Problem for Swift - @samwize
If you‚Äôre using Claude Code for iOS development, you‚Äôve probably noticed an annoying habit: it consistently adds trailing whitespace to your code. Those pesky spaces at the end of lines trigger SwiftLint warnings and clutter your git diffs.

entry.title: In SwiftUI, we often use elements without thinking much about how they actually work. Usually, this...

author.name: Readaggregator - iOS, Swift, Apple, Programming, Mobile

entry.content:
In SwiftUI, we often use elements without thinking much about how they actually work. Usually, this isn‚Äôt a problem, but sometimes understanding the implementation details helps explain unexpected behaviors. This knowledge can also come in handy during interviews, where such questions occasionally pop up.

In this article, the author takes a closer look at how Namespace works under the hood and why these details might matter.

p.s. If you‚Äôre interested in similar deep dives, the author also has an article about the Spacer in SwiftUI.

https://kyleye.top/posts/swiftui-namespace
#SwiftUI

Understanding SwiftUI's Namespace | Áü•ÈòÖÁôæÂæÆ ËßÅÂæÆÁü•Ëëó - Áü•ÈòÖÁôæÂæÆ ËßÅÂæÆÁü•Ëëó
Dive deep into SwiftUI's Namespace property wrapper - learn how it works internally, how to use it effectively for matched geometry effects, and best practices for creating fluid animations in your iOS apps.
